title: How to Convert a WAV File to a MP3 File

steps.headline: Search for a free online file converter.
steps.description: Type in ".wav to MP3 convert" into a search engine and find one that offers a free service.

steps.headline: Navigate to the section on the site where the conversion is offered.
steps.description: Sometimes, you have to navigate the site to find where the service is offered.

steps.headline: Import the .wav you want converted to MP3.
Choose the format you want to convert to, if necessary.
steps.description: Some sites will ask you to specify the format you want to convert to.

steps.headline: Decide where you want to send the file.
steps.description: Enter an email address that the converted file will sent to, if necessary. Sometimes, the file will be available for download on the site itself. Other times, you will need to enter an email address in order to retrieve it. If you are worried about getting spammed, use a sock-puppet email or create one for yourself. You can use this account to retrieve any files you need.

steps.headline: Find the "convert" button nearby.
steps.description: The file should be sent to your email address; some of the time, it will be zipped to accommodate larger files.

steps.headline: Open iTunes.
Navigate to iTunes → Preferences → Import Settings.
steps.description: If using iTunes 7 or earlier, you'll need to go to the "Advanced" tab before being able to access "Import Settings." If using iTunes 8 or later, going to "Preferences" will automatically direct you to the page where you can find "Advanced."

steps.headline: Set "Import Using" to "MP3 Encoder."
Choose a setting preference.
steps.description: Next to "Setting," choose either 128 kbps, 160 kbps, or 192 kbps. If you want a custom setting, click on "Custom..." and select choices for Stereo Bit Rate, Sample Rate, and Channels. Under most circumstances, you want your channel set to "Stereo."

steps.headline: Click "OK" to close the Import Settings window.
Click "OK" to close the General Preferences window.
Select one or more .wav files already in your iTunes.
Create an MP3 version of the file.
steps.description:
Depending on your version of iTunes, do this either by:
With the file(s) selected, navigate to the "Advanced" tab and choose Create MP3 Version. Simply right-click the file and click "Create MP3 Version."

steps.headline: Download the appropriate LAME MP3 encoder.
Unzip the archived LAME folder and remember its location.
Download and open the free cross-platform Audacity.
Select the File and choose the Open option.
Locate the desired WAV file on your computer's hard drive.
steps.description: A sound map of the file will appear in Audacity's main display.

steps.headline: Select the File tab and choose the Export as MP3 option.
Respond to the prompt by finding the MP3 encoder where you just chose to unzip it.
steps.description: The file will be called lame_enc.dll for Windows and libmp3lame.so for Macintosh. You will only be asked to do this the first time you use the Export as MP3 option.

steps.headline: Select the location you would like your converted MP3 file to appear in and rename the file if necessary.
steps.description: If you are converting a .wav file to .mp3 specifically to be able to play the file in iTunes then the iTunes music folder is an ideal location for the converted file.

tyn: An internet connection for downloading software, preferably a fast one.
text:
Free Online File Conversion Search for a free online file converter. Type in ".wav to MP3 convert" into a search engine and find one that offers a free service. Navigate to the section on the site where the conversion is offered. Sometimes, you have to navigate the site to find where the service is offered. Import the .wav you want converted to MP3.  Choose the format you want to convert to, if necessary. Some sites will ask you to specify the format you want to convert to. Decide where you want to send the file. Enter an email address that the converted file will sent to, if necessary. Sometimes, the file will be available for download on the site itself. Other times, you will need to enter an email address in order to retrieve it. If you are worried about getting spammed, use a sock-puppet email or create one for yourself. You can use this account to retrieve any files you need. Find the "convert" button nearby. The file should be sent to your email address; some of the time, it will be zipped to accommodate larger files. iTunes Open iTunes.  Navigate to iTunes → Preferences → Import Settings. If using iTunes 7 or earlier, you'll need to go to the "Advanced" tab before being able to access "Import Settings." If using iTunes 8 or later, going to "Preferences" will automatically direct you to the page where you can find "Advanced." Set "Import Using" to "MP3 Encoder."  Choose a setting preference. Next to "Setting," choose either 128 kbps, 160 kbps, or 192 kbps. If you want a custom setting, click on "Custom..." and select choices for Stereo Bit Rate, Sample Rate, and Channels. Under most circumstances, you want your channel set to "Stereo." Click "OK" to close the Import Settings window.  Click "OK" to close the General Preferences window.  Select one or more .wav files already in your iTunes.  Create an MP3 version of the file. Depending on your version of iTunes, do this either by:
With the file(s) selected, navigate to the "Advanced" tab and choose Create MP3 Version. Simply right-click the file and click "Create MP3 Version." Audacity Download the appropriate LAME MP3 encoder.  Unzip the archived LAME folder and remember its location.  Download and open the free cross-platform Audacity.  Select the File and choose the Open option.  Locate the desired WAV file on your computer's hard drive. A sound map of the file will appear in Audacity's main display. Select the File tab and choose the Export as MP3 option.  Respond to the prompt by finding the MP3 encoder where you just chose to unzip it. The file will be called lame_enc.dll for Windows and libmp3lame.so for Macintosh. You will only be asked to do this the first time you use the Export as MP3 option. Select the location you would like your converted MP3 file to appear in and rename the file if necessary. If you are converting a .wav file to .mp3 specifically to be able to play the file in iTunes then the iTunes music folder is an ideal location for the converted file.
sentences: Free Online File Conversion Search for a free online file converter.
Type in ".wav to MP3 convert" into a search engine and find one that offers a free service.
Navigate to the section on the site where the conversion is offered.
Sometimes, you have to navigate the site to find where the service is offered.
Import the .wav you want converted to MP3.
Choose the format you want to convert to, if necessary.
Some sites will ask you to specify the format you want to convert to.
Decide where you want to send the file.
Enter an email address that the converted file will sent to, if necessary.
Sometimes, the file will be available for download on the site itself.
Other times, you will need to enter an email address in order to retrieve it.
If you are worried about getting spammed, use a sock-puppet email or create one for yourself.
You can use this account to retrieve any files you need.
Find the "convert" button nearby.
The file should be sent to your email address; some of the time, it will be zipped to accommodate larger files.
iTunes Open iTunes.
Navigate to iTunes → Preferences → Import Settings.
If using iTunes 7 or earlier, you'll need to go to the "Advanced" tab before being able to access "Import Settings."
If using iTunes 8 or later, going to "Preferences" will automatically direct you to the page where you can find "Advanced."
Set "Import Using" to "MP3 Encoder."
Choose a setting preference.
Next to "Setting," choose either 128 kbps, 160 kbps, or 192 kbps.
If you want a custom setting, click on "Custom..." and select choices for Stereo Bit Rate, Sample Rate, and Channels.
Under most circumstances, you want your channel set to "Stereo."
Click "OK" to close the Import Settings window.
Click "OK" to close the General Preferences window.
Select one or more .wav files already in your iTunes.
Create an MP3 version of the file.

Depending on your version of iTunes, do this either by:
With the file(s) selected, navigate to the "Advanced" tab and choose Create MP3 Version.
Simply right-click the file and click "Create MP3 Version."
Audacity Download the appropriate LAME MP3 encoder.
Unzip the archived LAME folder and remember its location.
Download and open the free cross-platform Audacity.
Select the File and choose the Open option.
Locate the desired WAV file on your computer's hard drive.
A sound map of the file will appear in Audacity's main display.
Select the File tab and choose the Export as MP3 option.
Respond to the prompt by finding the MP3 encoder where you just chose to unzip it.
The file will be called lame_enc.dll for Windows and libmp3lame.so for Macintosh.
You will only be asked to do this the first time you use the Export as MP3 option.
Select the location you would like your converted MP3 file to appear in and rename the file if necessary.
If you are converting a .wav file to .mp3 specifically to be able to play the file in iTunes then the iTunes music folder is an ideal location for the converted file.
